abstract.text: We compare the relative contributions of filter-feeding and ammonium-nitrogen translocated from algal symbionts (zooxanthellae) towards the total nitrogen requirements for tissue growth and metabolism in the giant clam Tridacna gigus. Isotope enrichments suggest that zooxanthellae

body_text.text: effected most if not all primary assimilation from high concentrations (~15 PM) of "N-ammonium. There was a net daily uptake of ammonium from natural seawater, which was modulated according to nutritional history, light history, ammonium concentration, and possible biological rhythmicity. Zooxanthellae also assimilated nitrogen excreted by host tissues, including 15N absorbed from ingested alga. Nearly 100% of the 15N subsequently released from zooxanthellae was incorporated in host tissues, with no significant loss from the clam over at least 10 days. Zooxanthellae therefore conserve and recycle essentially all nitrogenous end-products within T. gigas, affording giant clams a nutritional advantage over non-symbiotic bivalves. In further contrast with heterotrophic bivalves from particle-rich environments, T. gigas show longer gut passage times and high net and gross efficiencies (78.1 -+ 9.4% and 99.2 i-0.4%, respectively) with which organic nitrogen is absorbed from ingested particles. Filter-feeding and/or other non-autotrophic processes were essential as a source of nitrogen to maintain observed rates of juvenile growth, but declined in significance with increasing clam size. Even under cloudy conditions of limited irradiance, the total contribution of nitrogen acquired as ammonium by zooxanthellae exceeded the contribution from ingested particles in T. gigas larger than about 0.1 g, increasing to at least 45% of total nitrogen requirements in clams of 10 g. The giant clam Tridacna gigas is a prime candidate for mariculture; for despite living within the oligotrophic environment of coral reefs throughout much of the Indo-Pacific, it is the largest and fastest-growing of all bivalve molluscs (Yonge, 1980; Crawford et al., 1987; Heslinga & Fitt, 1987; Lucas, 1994) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Although T. gigus is already being raised in hatcheries (Lucas, 1994) , the means by which this species achieves such spectacular growth, and the relative importance of different sources of nutrients, has remained controversial (Fankboner & Reid, 1990; Fitt, 1993; Lucas, 1994) . What is certain is that endosymbiotic algae known as zooxanthellae within the hypertrophied siphon (commonly refered to as mantle tissue) transfer excess carbon from photosynthesis to host tissues, possibly in quantities that are sufficient to satisfy respiratory requirements in T. maxima (Trench et al., 1981) , T. gigus (Fisher et al., 1985; Klumpp et al., 1992) , T. tevoroa and T. derusa (Klumpp and Lucas, 1994) . Southgate (1988) has also demonstrated assimilation of 14C-labelled carbohydrate and lipid from microcapsules ingested by T. gigus larvae. And recently, we have also helped to dispel earlier doubts over the importance of filter-feeding (e.g. Ricard & Salvat, 1977) , showing that particulate organic matter satisfied at least 65% of the total carbon needed for both the respiration and growth in small T. gigas (Klumpp et al., 1992) . Given the additional potential for direct uptake of dissolved organic matter (DOM) (Fankboner, 1971; Goreau et al., 1973) , it is clear that T. gigus is trophically opportunistic,
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: utilizing both autotrophic and heterotrohpic mechanisms to help satisfy nutritional requirements (Yonge, 1980; Heslinga & Fitt, 1987; Klumpp et al., 1992) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Nitrogen often limits growth in the marine environment. Yet there are no previous data quantifying the significance of zooxanthellae, filter-feeding, or DOM to the requirements for protein-nitrogen in T. gigus or any other comparable symbiotic organism.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Rather, research has focused on a further source of nutrition, establishing that giant clams may effect net uptake of dissolved inorganic nitrogen (Burris, 1983; Wilkerson & Trench, 1986; Fitt et al., 1993) , and that tissue growth is stimulated in response to the addition of nitrogen as ammonium or nitrate to surrounding seawater (Heslinga et al., 1990; Braley, 1992; Belda et al.. 1993) . It is generally accepted that net uptake of ammonium from the environment by intact zooxanthellae-host symbioses occurs by passive diffusion down concentration gradients that are created by localized substrate depletion (e.g. D'Elia et al., 1983) . Certainly, the haemolymph of T. gigus appears to be the immediate source of metabolites for zooxanthellae (Rees et al., 1993) which are able to assimilate ammonium for the synthesis of amino acids (Muscatine, 1980; Wilkerson & Muscatine, 1984; Summons et al., 1986; Anderson & Burris, 1987; Wilkerson & Trench, 1986) , and which occupy a unique tubular system that ramifies from a diverticulum of the stomach (Norton et al., 1992) . Further, the uptake of dissolved inorganic nitrogen by T. gigus is photodependent, and does not occur in isolated host tissues (Wilkerson & Trench, 1986; Fitt et al., 1993) . Therefore, the uptake of inorganic nitrogen by symbiotic associations appears at least partially dependent upon primary assimilation by zooxanthellae. It has been suggested that assimilation by zooxanthellae of ammonium-nitrogen excreted by the host, and the subsequent recycling of that nitrogen when released as amino acids utilized by host tissues, is central both to the rapid growth of tridacnid clams (Wilkerson & Trench, 1986; Lucas, 1994) and to the general success of algal-invertebrate symbioses in nutrient-poor waters (e.g. Muscatine & Porter, 1977; Spencer Davies, 1992) . However, there is little information on the fate of nitrogen assimilated by zooxanthellae (Griffiths & Streamer, 1988; Spencer Davies, 1992) . In addition, there is current debate on whether host waste nitrogenous products are freely available to algal symbionts (Douglas, 1988) and whether zooxanthellae are solely responsible for the assimilation of inorganic nutrients by the association. Having compared activities of both glutamine synthetase and glutamate dehydrogenase with ammonium flux with and without metabolic inhibitors in the Hydra-Chlorellu symbiosis, Rees (1987) suggested that ammonium assimilation occurs primarily in the host tissues. It has also been proposed that this assimilation allows the host to regulate its population of symbionts by restricting their source of nitrogen, supplied as amino acids (McAuley, 1987; Rees, 1987) , and that host-mediated assimilation occurs in symbioses involving zooxanthellae (Miller & Yellowlees, 1989) . These suggestions obviously question the extent to which ammonium-nitrogen excreted by the host is freely available for assimilation and recycling by zooxanthellae (Douglas, 1988; Rees, 1991) .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In a related publication, we have described natural growth rates, dark respiration, die1 oxygen flux and the absorption of organic matter from suspended particles filtered by T. gigas (Klumpp et al., 1992) . These results were used to quantify the relative roles of endosymbiotic photosynthates and filter-feeding in providing the carbon needed for growth and respiration.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Here, we report associated measures of die1 ammonium flux, host tissue excretion and the absorption of organic nitrogen from ingested food particles, together with studies that monitored the uptake and subsequent utilisation of nitrogen isotope 15N that was available to T. gigus both as dissolved "N-ammonium and "N-1abelled alga. Findings are used to assess the extent to which zooxanthellae may be responsible for primary assimilation of inorganic nitrogen, to establish whether ammoniumnitrogen excreted by the host is freely available for assimilation and recycling by the zooxanthellae, and to quantify size-dependent contributions both of filterfeeding and algal symbiosis towards the total amino-nitrogen requirements for clam tissue growth and metabolism.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The work described below was undertaken during June, 1988 using T. gigas from the mariculture unit at Orpheus Island Research Station (OIRS), North Queensland, Australia. Initially, these clams were reared to juvenile size within raceways as described by Crawford et al. (1986) . Clams were then transferred to the reef flat at 2 cm shell length, where they grew to experimental size (4-6 cm shell length) over the next 5 months.
body_text.section: Origin and maintenance of clams

body_text.text: Experiments using the stable isotope of nitrogen "N to study the uptake kinetics and subsequent utilisation of nitrogen were undertaken at OIRS. Experiments studying diurnal cycles or the effects of light-history on net fluxes of oxygen and/or ammonium were undertaken using clams transferred in May, 1988 from OIRS to the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS). Before experimentation, clams were acclimated in open-air flow-through raceways of unfiltered natural seawater for 3 days at OIRS, and up to 21 days at AIMS. Seawater was of similar temperature (22.5 2 3.O"C) at OIRS and at AIMS. Determinations of net absorption efficiency were undertaken on board the RV Harry Messel in the lagoon of Davies Reef (18.8"S, 147.2"E), using natural faecal pellets from clams that had previously been transplanted from OIRS to that lagoon in November, 1987.
body_text.section: Origin and maintenance of clams

body_text.text: A data-logging respirometer that monitors irradiance, temperature and oxygen tension in four replicate chambers at 1-min intervals (technical details and data analysis are described in Klumpp et al., 1987) was used to compare daily net fluxes of oxygen and ammonium-nitrogen under a natural light regime at AIMS. The respirometer was positioned immediately below the surface of seawater in the same open-air flow-through raceway to which clams had been acclimated. One clam of 11.5 to 12.1 (mean + 2 SE = 11.7 f 0.3) cm shell length was placed in each of the four respirometer chambers. Each chamber contained 2.5 1 of seawater, which was completely and automatically replaced by flushing at 90-min intervals throughout the 24 h of measurements. Net oxygen flux ( pmole . clam ' . h-') was determined by least-squares regression of PO, against the time between seawater flushings, and separate means computed for each of the 16 incubations undertaken per clam. To measure the average net ammonium flux ( pmole . clam ' . h-') for each clam during the same incubations, duplicate 15 ml seawater samples were collected by syringe through a 0.2 pm filter from rubber sampling ports. These samples were collected up to 3 min after flushing, and less than 5 min before the next water replacement. Control samples were collected in the same way from a beaker containing 2.5 seawater standing in the same raceway, replacing that seawater by hand at the times of respirometer flushing. All samples were frozen in capped polyethylene vials at -20°C which is known to stabilise ammonium concentrations (e.g. Degobbis, 1972) . Automated analyses of ammonium content were undertaken within 2 wk of sample collection as described by Ryle et al. (1981) . The sensitivity of these analyses was k-O.02 PM. Initial concentrations of ammonium in the incubation seawater -0.5 PM.
body_text.section: Measuring daily net fluxes of oxygen and ammonium-nitrogen

body_text.text: To establish effects of darkness on net ammonium flux (,uniole * clam-' * h-l), and to determine the relationship between clam size and excretion of ammoniumnitrogen by the host tissues, the same four individual clams that had been used to compare daily net fluxes of oxygen and ammonium-nitrogen (refer above), as well as two other size-classes (with shell lengths of 1.1 2 0.1 and 19.4 2 1.2 cm, respectively) that had been acclimated under identical conditions, were transferred to another flow-through raceway situated within a constant-temperature room (24.5 + 0.5"C). This indoor raceway was supplied with seawater which had been filtered (0.5 pm) to remove all food particles. After one day, net ammonium fluxes were measured under an irradiance of 600 ,uE. rn-*. s-' from a 500-W quartz halide lamp. Clams were then maintained in total darkness, and net ammonium fluxes monitored after 2, 6, 10 and 13 days.
body_text.section: Establishing the effects of darkness and clam size on net fluxes of ammonium-nitrogen

body_text.text: Net ammonium fluxes were measured by incubating four clams from each of the large and intermediate size-classes separately within beakers containing 8 and 2 1 of membrane-filtered (0.25 pm) seawater, respectively. For the smallest size class, two clams were incubated together in beakers containing 50 ml of seawater, for each of six replicate groups. Each incubation was standardized over 4 h in the same constant temperature room (24.5 2 0.5"C). Red light of low intensity was used to see during those incubations. Duplicate 15 ml seawater samples were collected at the beginning and end of each incubation by syringe through a 0.2 pm filter. Samples were then stored at -20°C before measuring ammonium contents using phenol-hyperchlorite according to Grasshoff & Johannsen (1972) .
body_text.section: Establishing the effects of darkness and clam size on net fluxes of ammonium-nitrogen

body_text.text: To establish whether starving clams of suspended particles influenced rate of ammonium uptake, six clams were taken from the open air raceway that contained natural unfiltered seawater at OIRS. They were subsequently isolated for 48 h within separate beakers containing 2 1 of membrane-filtered (0.2 ,um) seawater, changing that seawater at 12-h intervals, whilst the beakers were positioned in that same raceway. Ammonium uptake by these particle-starved clams was then compared with that of a further six clams from natural unfiltered seawater.

body_text.text: All clams were 4.5 to 5.5 cm shell length, with a dry tissue weight of 238 2 26 mg. Each clam was incubated separately in glass beakers containing 400 ml of membrane-filtered (0.2 ,um) seawater spiked with NH,Cl to an initial concentration of 15 PM, whilst situated within the raceway of prior acclimation. Duplicate 5 ml seawater samples were collected after 0, 30, 60, 90, 120, 150, 180 and 210 min from incubations of particle-fed clams, but only after 0 and 210 min from particle-starved clams, and each sample analysed immediately for ammonium content using phenol-hyperchlorite according to Grasshoff & Johannsen (1972) .

body_text.text: To monitor the subsequent fate of ammonium-nitrogen assimilated by particlefed clams, the NH,Cl used to spike these incubations of particle-fed clams was isotopically-labelled such that more than 99% of all ammonium-nitrogen was "N (Europa Scientific Limited, Crewe, UK). A total of 39 clams from natural unfiltered seawater were incubated as described above. Following 210 min of incubation within ammonium-"N chloride, these particle-fed clams were returned to the open air raceway, and four clams sampled after 0.25, 2, 4, 6, 24, 48, 94 and 245 h. All zooxanthellae were immediately collected from the mantle of each clam by homogenisation and centrifugation. Each mantle was homogenised in 5 ml filtered seawater using an Ultra Turrax homogeniser at full speed for 1 min. The homogenate was then centrifuged at 1000 rpm for 5 min, before retaining the pelleted zooxanthellae.

body_text.text: In addition, the foot, adductor muscle and gills, which contain less than 10% of all zooxanthellae within the clam, were collectively homogenised and centrifuged as described above. Regular microscopic examination not only confirmed the purity of our pelleted zooxanthellae, but also that the supernatant, including the "cap" of homogenised tissues sitting on the surface of that supernatant, was only comprised of animal cells and bacteria. Therefore, the supernatant and "cap" from collective homogenisations of foot, adductor muscle and gills were retained as host tissue. Each sample was placed within a screw-top glass vial, and dried to constant weight at 60°C before capping and storage.

body_text.text: To confirm the assimilation of inorganic nitrogen by zooxanthellae, and to determine the proportional translocation of nitrogen assimilated by zooxanthellae to host tissues, the percentage abundance of stable isotope "N was later measured within these samples of zooxanthellae or host tissues using continuousflow isotope-ratio mass spectrometry (Europa Scientific ANCA-MS).

body_text.text: To allow calculations of the total abundance of '"N, we dissociated the zooxanthellae from all tissues of five individual clams of similar size (4.5 to 5.5 cm shell length, with a mean ? 2 SE dry tissue weight of 231 2 8 mg). This was done by homogenising mantle and non-mantle tisssues separately, resuspending and centrifuging the pellet of zooxanthellae three times for each sample, using a whirlimixer to resuspend the pellet in filtered seawater, and discarding all supernatants. Microscopic observation then established no remaining "contamination" by host tissue, before pooling the pelleted zooxanthellae from each clam onto separate 4.7 cm GFC filters. We also excised the total soft tissues from a further four clams, and dried all samples to constant weight at low temperature (60°C) before storage in a desiccator. The total soft tissues were ground to a powder with mortar and pestle, and the protein contents both of zooxanthellae and total soft tissues determined according to Lowry et al. (1951) . Nitrogen equivalents were computed by dividing total protein by 5.8 (Gnaiger & Bitterlich, 1984) before calculating the average total nitrogen within zooxanthellae and host tissues (by difference) for these six clams. These average total nitrogen values were multiplied by individual measures of the fractional enrichment of r5N above natural background levels to give the enrichment (pg. clam-') of "N within either the zooxanthellae or host tissues. It is worth emphasising two points here: (1) we were conservative in keeping only the purist fractions of host tissue or zooxanthellae for 15N analyses; and (2) the absolute enrichments of 15N within all zooxanthellae or all host tissues from each clam were calculated by multiplying the measured fraction of "N in each sample by accurate measures of the total nitrogen in either the zooxanthellae or host tissues from other clams of similar size. By these means, each sample retained for 15N analysis did not depend on the complete separation of all zooxanthellae from all host tissues within each clam. Following the incubation of clams in ammonium-'5N chloride, to quantify the subsequent egestion of "N in faeces, the six clams that had previously been particle-starved as described above were immediately transferred to shallow open-topped beakers submerged within the raceway of acclimation. All faeces produced by each clam were collected for filtration onto 2.5 cm GFC filters following intervals of 6, 24 and 48 h. The filters were dried to constant weight at 60°C and stored in a desiccator before analysing each sample both for total nitrogen content and the abundance of stable isotope "N.
body_text.section: Determining ammonium uptake both by particle-fed or particle-starved clams, the proportional translocation of nitrogen from zooxanthellae to host tissues, and faecal losses of nitrogen assimilated as dissolved ammonium

body_text.text: Absorption efficiencies for ingested particles were measured in clams feeding upon natural seston in the lagoon of Davies Reef using the ash to ash-free ratio method of Conover (1966) . Faeces were collected, and correction made for pellets that contained healthy undigested zooxanthellae, as described by Klumpp et al. (1992) . Nitrogen contents of food and faeces were determined using an elemental combustion analyser (Carlo Erba 1108) with acetanilide standards. The above measures are of net absorption efficiencies, taking into account metabolic faecal losses that are secreted into but not reabsorbed from the gut (Hawkins & Bayne, 1992) . To measure the gross efficiency of absorption, which takes no account of metabolic faecal losses, as well as to measure approximate gut passage time, and to confirm the uptake by zooxanthellae of nitrogen absorbed across the hosts gut epithelium, a culture of the unicellular alga Zsochrysis galbana was homogenously labelled with '"N as described by Hawkins & Bayne (1984) . This labelled alga was separated from '"N-labelled medium by centrifuging (2500 rpm for 5 min) and resuspending in filtered seawater two times before being administered to 38 clams of 5.5 to 6.5 cm shell length, with a dry tissue weight of 464 + 28 mg. Each clam was maintained for 4 h within separate beakers, each containing 4 1 of the same unfiltered seawater to which clams had acclimated, having added sufficient labelled alga to achieve an initial concentration of 7500 I.

Immediately following this incubation, aliquots of the 15Nlabelled culture, as well as all '"N-labelled alga remaining within the beakers that had been used to incubate 6 of the 38 clams, were collected separately on 4.7 cm GFC filters. The same six clams were transferred to shallow open-topped beakers submerged within natural unfiltered seawater in the raceway of acclimation. All faeces produced by each of these six clams were subsequently pipetted onto separate 2.5 cm GFC filters after intervals of 1.2, 2, 3, 4, 5, 8, 9, 10.75 and 21 h. Filters were dried to constant weight at 6O"C, and stored in a desiccator before analysing each sample for the abundance of stable isotope "N. Ingestion of "N was calculated by subtracting the algal '"N that remained in each beaker after the removal of clams from the amount initially added to each beaker. Gross assimilation efficiency for "N was then calculated separately for each clam as [((15N ingested)-(total '"N egested as faeces over 21 h)) + ('"N ingested)] X 100. Regression analyses of the cumulative egestions of faecal 15N over time were used to estimate gut passage time as the interval after which 95% of all "N had been egested, applying a reciprocal square root transformation according to Bayne et al. (1989) .

body_text.section: The effects of darkness on net fluxes of ammonium-nitrogen

body_text.text: Changes in net ammonium flux (pmole . clam-' . h-') over 13 days following the transfer of three size classes of clam from full light to total darkness are illustrated in Fig. 1 . Immediately before excluding all light, there was a mean net influx of ammonium in the larger size classes. But after 2 days darkness, statistically significant (p < 0.01) effluxes were recorded, which increased before reaching plateaux after 10 and 6 days, respectively (Fig. 1) . In contrast, significant (p < 0.001) net effluxes of ammonium were recorded in the smallest size class even before their transfer to darkness. Whilst net effluxes of ammonium in this group increased slightly after a further 2 days darkness, they remained unchanged (p > 0.05) thereafter (Fig. 1) . Therefore, relative to larger clams, net ammonium flux in smaller clams was less dependent upon light. Associated with these losses of ammonium-nitrogen, 33% of all experimental clams from the smallest size class had died after 13 days whilst starved of particles in total darkness. There was no mortality in either of the larger size classes.

body_text.text: Even on this overcast day, we observed large net production of oxygen, which occured at rates that were symmetrical about each peak in irradiance (Fig. 2) . Clams that had been feeding upon natural particles took up ammonium at only half the rate of those that had been maintained for the preceeding 48 h in filtered seawater (t value = 5.66, df = 10, p < 0.0001) (Fig. 3) . body_text.text: We have established that zooxanthellae effected most, if not all, primary assimilation of dissolved ammonium taken up from the surrounding seawater by T. gigas (Figs. 3 and 5) . In addition both to that primary assimilation and to the uptake of endogenous protein-nitrogen excreted following the catabolism of host tissue, zooxanthellae assimilate ammonium deriving from deamination by the host tissues of exogenous protein-nitrogen that has recently been absorbed from ingested particulates (Fig. 6 ). Such assimilation was not included within our above measures of AZS, that were calculated as NAF in particle-fed clams during daylight plus EN measured in particle-starved clams during prolonged darkness. (Fig. 3) . Such uptake also required exposure to light (Figs. 1 and 2 ) (cf. Wilkerson & Trench, 1986) . Compared with net oxygen fluxes, net ammonium fluxes were not as dependent upon irradiance, so that net uptake continued well into the night, although declining to a state of net efflux (Fig. 2) . In addition, net uptake recommenced at least 1 h before first light, implying associated biological periodicity (Fig. 2) . The result was that we recorded significant net daily uptake of ammonium by T. gigas monitored over 24 h in natural unspiked seawater containing about 0.5 FM ammonium (Fig. 2) . Stimulation of net ammonium uptake in response to starvation, and the continuing net uptake of ammonium for several hours in darkness, both imply the compensatory filling of internal pools, as is consistent with passive diffusion down concentration gradients created by localized substrate depletion (refer Introduction). Zooxanthellae comprise 8% of the total protein content of the symbiosis (refer Results). Yet after 3 h incubation in ammonium-"N chloride, more than 50% of the 15N retained by T. gigus was present in zooxanthellae (Fig. 4) ; and the mean (22 SE) atom% enrichment of lSN within zooxanthellae was 5.554 +-1.546%, compared with only 0.370 + 0.022% in host tissues. Given that some of the 15N in host tissues must have been 15N-ammonium within haemolymph, this suggests that zooxanthellae were responsible for most if not all primary assimilation of the 15N-labelled ammonium.
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: Certainly, it is well-established in anthozoan symbiosis systems that photosynthesis is required to provide the carbon skeletons for assimilation of inorganic nitrogen (Muscatine & D'Elia, 1978) . However, it should be remembered that the initial concentration (15 ,uM) of the present pulse of "N-1abelled ammonium was well in excess of natural levels. Where host tissues do assimilate significant ammonium, as in the Hydra-Chlorellu symbiosis (Rees, 1987 (Rees, , 1991 and refer Introduction) , then the pathway effecting that assimilation is usually fully saturated (Spencer Davies, 1992) . Therefore, when a clam is exposed to high concentrations of ammonium, as in the present study, symbiotic algae will assimilate any ammonium not assimilated by hosts tissues. It follows that assimilation of ammonium by host tissues may be of proportionally greatest significance when there is little ammonium within the surrounding seawater. Our findings also establish the rapid direct uptake by zooxanthellae of nitrogen that had been absorbed by host tissues from ingested alga (Fig. 6) . Within 22 h of ingesting that alga, zooxanthellae contained [2.7 + (2.7 + 23.9)] X 100 = 10% of all the '"N that had been absorbed by each clam (refer Results). Given that zooxanthellae comprise 8% of all protein in the T. gigas symbiosis, this again suggests unrestricted access by the zooxanthellae to nitrogen, which in this case was within amino acids and/or ammonium deriving from the hosts digestion and/or deamination of ingested nutrients. Griffiths & Streamer (1988) showed that the major early products of 14Cphotosynthesis in T. gigas include glucose, oligosaccharides and amino acids, and described how these products are each translocated from zooxanthellae to the host. Our findings suggest that most if not all the nitrogen within those amino acids had been first assimilated by zooxanthellae, rather than by host tissues. We have also shown that an average of 94.7 (83.8, 106.9)% of the "N released by zooxanthellae was subsequently incorporated within host tissues (Fig. 4 , and refer Results). Carbon budgets suggest that the host receives a similar proportion of 90 to 95% of the carbon that is fixed daily by zooxanthellae (Fitt, 1993) . But perhaps most striking are present observations that enrichments by "N in both the zooxanthellae and host tissues remained statistically unchanged from 22 h up until at least 189 h after ingesting 15N-labelled alga (Fig. 6) , and that the atom% "N within total soft tissues of T. gigas remained statistically unchanged for at least 10 days after incubation in ammonium-'"N chloride (refer Results). Therefore, collective findings indicate that zooxanthellae help to recycle and conserve close to 100% of all the nitrogenous end-products excreted by host tissues. Such impressive retentions could only be achieved if essentially all ammonium-I J. Exp. Mar. Biol. Ecol. 190 (1995) 263-290 nitrogen excreted by the host is freely available for assimilation and recycling by the zooxanthellae in T. gigas. This is in obvious contrast to what has been proposed for the the Hydra-Chlorella symbiosis (McAuley, 1987; Rees, 1987 Rees, , 1991 and refer Introduction) .

body_text.text: Such high retentions are also of interest given the observation that giant clams persistently release live, whole zooxanthellae in their faeces (Ricard & Salvat, 1977; Lucas, 1993) . Similar release was observed in the present study, suggesting that the loss of nitrogen in undigested zooxanthellae is trivial, when considered as a proportion of the total uptake. Indeed, we have shown that less than 1% of all '"N assimilated by zooxanthellae was lost within faeces collected over the following 48 h (refer Results).
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: As an example among lamellibranchs lacking algal symbionts, retention efficiencies do not exceed 90% of the protein-nitrogen absorbed in Mytilus edulis of similar dry tissue weight (Hawkins & Bayne, 1991) . The higher efficiency observed here is clearly of major ecological significance, helping to explain how T. gigas achieves the fastest tissue growth of any bivalve, despite living in waters that are notoriously poor in nitrogen (refer Introduction). These findings also confirm that this symbiosis is of mutual benefit, with an evident selective advantage over free-living plants and animals, and which helps to explain the general success of similar symbioses in coral reef environments.
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: Quite apart from the uptake of inorganic nitrogen, we have confirmed that T. gigas also functions as a typical filter-feeder, utilizing the suspended particulate matter available in reef waters (Klumpp et al., 1992) . Here, we report an average (22 SE) gut passage time of 14.4 5 8.7 h in T. gigas of 464 2 28 mg dry tissue weight. This is far longer than a gut passage time of about 2.9 h in the lamellibranch mussel M. edulis of similar size, as predicted using an established weight exponent (Hawkins et al., 1990) applied to equivalent data for mussels feeding actively in a particle-rich environment (Bayne et al., 1989) . Longer gut passage times increase the potential for extraction of nutrients from ingested matter, thus helping to explain why both net and gross absorption efficiencies recorded here for organic nitrogen in T. gigas (78.1 -+ 9.4% and 99.2 2 0.4%, respectively) were very much higher than previously recorded in M. edulis (56.1 ? 35.5% and 80.8 2 1.7%, respectively; Hawkins and Bayne, 1984) . As a possible explanation both of longer gut passage time and such high assimilation efficiencies, Yonge (1936) observed that the ducts leading into the digestive diverticula of tridacnid clams appear exceptionally wide, that "every opportunity is taken of passing material into them", and that "only as a last resort is it (material) passed into the mid-gut" (p. 294). This suggests that, compared with other lamellibranchs, a far higher proportion of the particles ingested by T. gigas are digested

However, we favour the first explanation, involving greater intracellular digestion and longer gut passage times. The remainder of this discussion will consider metabolic requirements for nitrogen, and the relative extent to which filter-feeding and nitrogen taken up as ammonium before translocation from zooxanthellae satisfy those requirements in T. gigus of different dry tissue weight. Therefore, if starved of particles, the host tissues of adult clams may obtain all basal nitrogen requirements from zooxanthellae, and larger T. gigus may actually be in positive nitrogen balance, although any growth would be slower than in clams feeding upon natural particles.

body_text.text: In particle-fed clams, translocation of the nitrogen acquired as ammonium by zooxanthellae contributed an estimated 11% of the total requirements for tissue growth and metabolism in small clams of 0.001 g dry tissue weight, but this contribution increased with body size to a maximum of 45% in clams of 10 g dry tissue weight (Fig. 7, Table  1 ). Alternatively, nitrogen ingested as particles contributed as much as 63% of the total requirements of very small clams, declining steadily to only 23% in clams of 10 g dry tissue weight (Fig. 7, Table 1 ). We have earlier reported that T. gigas smaller than about 0.1 g dry tissue weight require carbon intake from both ingested particles and zooxanthellae to achieve observed rates of growth (Klumpp et al., 1992) . Here, the contribution from filter-feeding towards total nitrogen requirements began to exceed the estimated contribution from algal symbionts in T. gigas of less than the same size (about 0.1 g dry tissue weight; Fig. 7) . In addition, it is notable that total host tissue excretion represented a fairly constant proportion (0.37 ? 0.02, mean & 2 SE) of the total requirements for growth and metabolism in each size class (n = 4), so that zooxanthellae only began to contribute more nitrogen than was already excreted and recycled within clams larger than about 0.1 g dry tissue weight (Fig. 7) (Table  1) . Clearly, ingested particles and/or other non-autotrophic processes (refer below) were essential as a source of both the carbon and nitrogen required for observed rates of growth in juvenile T. gigas.
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: Greater observed dependence on suspended particulates and/or other nonautotrophic processes among small T. gigas should not be suprising. Clam larvae acquire all their zooxanthellae from surrounding seawater, so that newlymetamorphosed clams have fewer symbionts during the early stages of infection with zooxanthellae (Fitt et al., 1986 (Fitt et al., , 1993 Fitt, 1993) . This helps to explain why, when starved of particles, T. gigas larvae did not survive beyond metamorphosis (Southgate, 1988) . Similarly, in the present study, small T. gigas were the first to die when particle-starved during prolonged darkness (refer Results). Presumably, compared with larger clams, those smallest individuals and larvae lacked sufficient zooxanthellae to retain and recycle as much of the ammonium excreted when host tissues catabolized structural proteins as the main source of energy. Under natural cycles of daylight, greater dependence of small T. gigas on suspended particles may also reflect the observation that zooxanthellae are increasingly shaded as the mantle becomes relatively thicker in larger clams, with the result that photosynthetic rates in juvenile T. gigus become saturated at levels of irradiance that are commonly below ambient, whereas photosynthetic rates in larger clams are not saturated at even the highest natural light intensities (Fisher et al., 1985) . Although not as obvious in gross terms, it should be remembered that particulate feeding may continue to play a lifelong role in helping to satisfy more specific requirements for essential amino acids, phosphorus and/or trace metals. Irrespective of size, ingested particles and ammonium-nitrogen acquired by zooxanthellae together satisfied a constant proportion of about 70% of total amino-nitrogen requirements for observed tissue growth and metabolism (Fig. 7 ). Yet ingested particles and zooxanthellae more than satisfied the total requirements for carbon; those requirements having been computed using the same observed rates of particle filtration and tissue growth ( Fig. 7 ; data from Klumpp et al., 1992) . There are at least three possible explanations for this apparent shortfall in amino-nitrogen:
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: (1) Average net uptake of dissolved ammonium by T. gigus at Davies Reef may have been significantly higher than measured in our experimental seawater at AIMS. Indeed, we wonder if the net daily uptake of ammonium recorded at AIMS would have been higher on a brighter day, for irradiance was only half than expected on a cloudless day (refer Results). Ammonium uptake is certainly dependent upon light (Figs. 1 and 2) (cf. Wilkerson & Trench, 1986 ). although nothing is known of whether net uptake may be enhanced at greater irradiances.
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: A further possibility is that by measuring net flux in closed systems, we may have limited the availability of ammonia, thereby underestimating natural fluxes within the open sea. (2) T. gigus may effect net uptake of dissolved inorganic nitrogen either as ammonium or nitrate (Wilkerson and Trench, 1986; Fitt et al., 1993) both of which stimulate tissue growth (Heslinga et al., 1990; Braley, 1992; Belda et al., 1993) . Rates of nitrate uptake were consistently less than of ammonium uptake, when offered separately (Fitt et al., 1993) and nothing is known of any possible ammonium repression of nitrate uptake. However, we have recorded concentrations of up to 1.0 ,uM nitrate on the back of the reef flat at Davies Reef, compared with an associated maximum of 0.45 ,uM ammonium (Klumpp & Hawkins, unpubl. data) . Therefore, it is possible that T. gigas assimilated dissolved nitrogen as nitrate whilst growing on Davies Reef. (3) Some of the "missing" nitrogen may have been acquired by T. gigas as dissolved organic matter (DOM). The epidermis of T. gigus mantle is highly convoluted, being made up of microvilli with micropinocytotic channels, and therefore appears adapted for the active uptake of DOM (Fankboner, 1971 ). The only confirmation of such uptake in tridacnids has been the work of Goreau et al. (1973) , who described incorporation of [3H]-leucine from ambient seawater into the mantle and ctenidial epithelia of T. maxima. In other non-symbiotic bivalves, relatively recent work using high performance liquid chromatography under bacteria-free conditions has confirmed the uptake both of amino acids and sugars, which appear to satisfy very significant proportions of up to at least 24% of measured energy expenditure (Hawkins & Bayne, 1991) . Admittedly, uptake of DOM may only be important as a source of energy in small T. gigas, or during prolonged darkness. But as a potential additional source of amino-nitrogen, then DOM may be of greater general significance.
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: In conclusion, the spectacular growth of T. gigus results from a number of complementary processes. This study has established that organic nitrogen is absorbed with exceptional efficiencies from ingested particulates, due in part to slow gut passage times that may reflect a high proportion of intracellular digestion.
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: Alternatively, and despite current uncertainties raised by work on the Hydra-Chlorella symbiosis (refer Introduction), our results indicate that ammonium-nitrogen excreted by the host is freely available for assimilation and recycling by the zooxanthellae in T. gigas. The giant clam therefore retains and conserves essentially all nitrogenous end-products, which would otherwise be excreted from bivalves without algal symbionts.
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: In additional contrast to normal heterotrophic bivalves, zooxanthellae enable T. gigus to obtain dissolved inorganic nitrogen from surrounding natural seawater. Added potential for increased uptake from transient pulses both of ammonium and nitrate, as well as the (enhanced) ability to absorb nutrients from ingested particles, collectively enable opportunistic acquisition according to circumstance. This means that the relative contributions from any one source are likely to differ with geographic location, environmental condition, and developmental stage. For example, we have shown that net uptake of inorganic nitrogen by zooxanthellae in large clams was modulated according to nutritional history, light history, and the concentration of available ammonium.
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: However, such uptake was not as significant in small clams, that required ingested particles and/or other non-autotrophic processes for observed growth. Further work is needed to establish the effects of irradiance on uptake of DIN, and to quantify uptake of DOM as a potential additional non-autotrophic source of nitrogen.
body_text.section: Relative contributions of zooxanthellae and filter-feeding to host nutrition

body_text.text: To help understand the true role of algal symbiosis, it will also be necessary to compare specific amino acid requirements of the host with what may be provided from zooxanthellae, as DOM, and/or from ingested particles.

Therefore, we have estimated this excretion of exogenous nitrogen by host tissues (EX, mg N. d-') in T. gigas as 0.12 X protein absorption (Table 1) . To calculate the total assimilation of ammonium-nitrogen by zooxanthellae in particle-fed T. gigas (AZF) (mg N. day-'), we assume that zooxanthellae assimilate all of both the endogenous and exogenous nitrogen excreted as ammonium by host tissues before that nitrogen is lost from the clam. This is probably not appropriate for the smallest T. gigas, as particle-starved clams smaller than about 0.06 mg dry tissue weight showed net losses of ammonium (refer Eq. 2 above). However, this would result in an overestimation of the nitrogen assimilated by zooxanthellae, and thus will not affect our conclusion that zooxanthellae contribute only a small fraction of the total nitrogen requirements of very young clams (refer Discussion).On this basis, AZF (mg N. day-') has been calculated as (AZS + EX) (Table  1) . In turn, we have computed the contribution of ammonium-nitrogen translocated from zooxanthellae (AT) to help satisfy the clam's nitrogen requirements as the total uptake of ammoniumnitrogen by zooxanthellae (AZF) multiplied by the mean fraction (0.95) of "N which, released from zooxanthellae, was subsequently incorporated within host tissues of our experimental clams ( Fig. 4 ) ( Table 1) . Fig. 7 illustrates the relative calculated contributions of organic nitrogen absorbed from filtered particles (A) and ammonium-nitrogen translocated from zooxanthellae (AT) towards the total requirements for observed tissue growth and metabolism (G + U) (Table 1) . Nitrogen absorbed from ingested particles represented the main estimated contribution (>63%) to the total requirements of very small clams, but this contribution declined steadily with increasing size to only 23% in clams of 10 g dry tissue weight. Alternatively, whilst almost insignificant in the smallest clams, the estimated contribution from zooxanthellae increased with size, becoming greater than from ingested particles for clams larger than about 0.1 g dry tissue weight. Irrespective of clam size, the collective contributions from both filtered particles and the ammonium translocated from zooxanthellae together satisfied a constant proportion of about 70% of the total requirements for observed tissue growth and metabolism ( Fig. 7 ).

Our results confirm rapid non-saturating uptake of ammonium by T. gigas exposed to spiked seawater enriched to concentrations of up to 15 ,uM (Fig. 3 ). Similar findings have been reported both for T. crocea (Burris, 1983) and T. gigus (Wilkerson & Trench, 1986; Fitt et al., 1993) . Presumably, this capacity for opportunistic uptake enables T. gigus to capitalise upon transient pulses in the natural environment, for greater availabilities of dissolved inorganic nitrogen are known to enhance tissue growth of the clam host (refer Introduction).Among the novel findings reported here, net uptake of ammonium by T. gigus was modulated by previous nutritional history, doubling in particle-starved clams animals.
